text: Imagine picking up a tool and thinking _I haven't put any effort into using this so it doesn't work the way I want_, and then going around and shaking it at people and telling them how bad it is.

text:
I think the convention of counting from 0 in math became popular when set theory was coming into shape. Textbooks in the last few decades seem to favour indexing sequences starting from 0. For example, the Wikipedia defines the Fibonacci number starting with F_0. <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fibonacci_numbers>
It just seems that Julia follows the convention that Matlab uses which is a reasonable thing to do. But since Julia allows custom indexing, I don't think it's a big problem.

elements.text: I think the convention of counting from 0 in math became popular when set theory was coming into shape. Textbooks in the last few decades seem to favour indexing sequences starting from 0. For example, the Wikipedia defines the Fibonacci number starting with F_0.
It just seems that Julia follows the convention that Matlab uses which is a reasonable thing to do. But since Julia allows custom indexing, I don't think it's a big problem.

text: ah come on, let's not go there, let's not judge or shame people based on whether their site is SSSl enabled (or devalue their opinion about Julia based on that). Besides, that looks like a site run by the department -- and I've been in plenty situations where it was difficult to impossible to coax admins into supporting SSL (or ensuring that certs stay up-to-date -- case in point, the cert for one of my departments server expired 5 days ago, and I can't reach any of the responsible staff rightnow). So I think it's unfair to attribute that to him

elements.text: ah come on, let's not go there, let's not judge or shame people based on whether their site is SSSl enabled (or devalue their opinion about Julia based on that). Google ranks your site better and you avoid the large "unsafe" warnings in browsers which may scare some people away
